title: Sri Lanka stock market edges up amid eroding sentiment over political deadlock
body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s stock market closed 0.17 percent higher on Friday (29) after skyrocketing in the two previous sessions as positive sentiment eroded amid a lingering political crisis threatened the recovery from an economic crisis.
The main All Share Price Index (ASPI) gained 12.83 points to 7,624.26 at the close.
The most liquid index S&P SL20 gained 0.22 percent or 5.51 points to close at 2,509.24.

Market analysts said, the market started moving on bargain hunting and Mark Mobius, a top emerging market investor also boosting market sentiments, however the uncertainties in the economic and political front still persist.

Youth-led protests demanding the resignation of President Gotabaya Rajapaksa continued for a 21st day on Friday while a looming political deadlock with the President and his brother Prime Minister Mahinda Rajapaksa defying resignations has threatened the current government’s ability in addressing the current economic crisis, analysts say.
On Monday and Tuesday, the market closed within minutes after it opened for trade because of the 10 percent circuit breaker losing over 11 percent.

The Colombo Stock Exchange (CSE) was closed from April 11 to 18 due to a traditional new year; however during that period Sri Lanka’s Central Bank raised its key policy rates by 7-percent, announced a soft-default and began IMF discussions amid sovereign rating downgrade.
The CSE also closed the market for another five days, citing investors’ need for a cool off period to make informed decisions.
The day’s turnover was 2.4 billion rupees, more than half of this year’s average daily turnover of 4.5 billion rupees.
Investors are also concerned over the steep fall in the rupee.
Sri Lanka’s rupee has fallen nearly 75 percent since it was allowed flexibility on March 7.

The market lost 14.4 percent in April after plunging 23 percent in March and 11 percent in the previous month. Overall the market has lost 37.6 percent so far this year after being one of the world’s best stock markets with an 80 percent return last year.
Foreign investors bucked the trend and bought a net 62.7 million rupees worth of shares. However, the market has witnessed a total foreign outflow of 1.31 billion rupees so far this year.
LOLC, John Keells and Ceylinoc Insurance pushed the index up on Friday.

Shares in LOLC Holdings gained 5.9 percent to close at 437.50 rupees a share, John Keells Holdings ended 2.7 percent up at 123 rupees a share while Ceylinco Insurance gained 3.9 percent to close at 1,953.25 rupees a share. (Colombo/April29/2022)
